prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in engineering would.
problem_prompt:
Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in engineering would. Let $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c}$ be three unit vectors, such that the angle between any of them is the acute angle $\theta.$  The volume of the tetrahedron generated by these three vectors is $\frac{1}{\sqrt{360}}.$  Find
\[3 \cos^2 \theta - 2 \cos^3 \theta.\]
gpt_response:
We have that the volume of the tetrhedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} |(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \cdot \mathbf{c}|.\]Since $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c}$ are unit vectors, $\mathbf{a} \cdot (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \text{det}[\mathbf{a} \quad \mathbf{b} \quad \mathbf{c}].$  Let
\[\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \alpha \\ \sin \alpha \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \ \mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \beta \\ 0 \\ \sin \beta \end{pmatrix}, \ \mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ \cos \gamma \\ \sin \gamma \end{pmatrix}.\]Then the volume of the tetrhedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} \left| \begin{pmatrix} \cos \alpha & \sin \alpha & 0 \\ \cos \beta & 0 & \sin \beta \\ 0 & \cos \gamma & \sin \gamma \end{pmatrix} \right| = \frac{1}{6} |\cos \alpha (\sin \beta \sin \gamma) - \sin \alpha (\cos \beta \cos \gamma)|\]Let $\theta$ be the angle between $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b},$ so $\alpha + \beta = \theta,$ and let $\phi$ be the angle between $\mathbf{b}$ and $\mathbf{c},$ so $\beta + \gamma = \phi.$  Then
\[\cos \alpha (\sin \beta \sin \gamma) - \sin \alpha (\cos \beta \cos \gamma) = \cos \alpha \cos \phi \sin \gamma - \sin \alpha \sin \phi \cos \gamma\]Expanding, we get
\[\cos \theta \cos \phi \sin \gamma - \sin \theta \sin \phi \cos \gamma = \cos (\theta + \phi - \gamma).\]Hence, the volume of the tetrahedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} \left| \cos \theta \cos \phi \sin \gamma - \sin \theta \sin \phi \cos \gamma \right| = \frac{1}{6} |\cos (\theta + \phi - \gamma)|.\]Thus,
\[3 \cos^2 \theta - 2 \cos^3 \theta = 3 \cos \theta - 2 \cos \theta = \cos \theta.\]Therefore, our final answer is $\boxed{\cos \theta}.$
solution_prompt:
The following is a response to a question. Yes or no, is the final solution obtained in the following response \frac{9}{10}?: We have that the volume of the tetrhedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} |(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b}) \cdot \mathbf{c}|.\]Since $\mathbf{a},$ $\mathbf{b},$ and $\mathbf{c}$ are unit vectors, $\mathbf{a} \cdot (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) = \text{det}[\mathbf{a} \quad \mathbf{b} \quad \mathbf{c}].$  Let
\[\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \alpha \\ \sin \alpha \\ 0 \end{pmatrix}, \ \mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} \cos \beta \\ 0 \\ \sin \beta \end{pmatrix}, \ \mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 \\ \cos \gamma \\ \sin \gamma \end{pmatrix}.\]Then the volume of the tetrhedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} \left| \begin{pmatrix} \cos \alpha & \sin \alpha & 0 \\ \cos \beta & 0 & \sin \beta \\ 0 & \cos \gamma & \sin \gamma \end{pmatrix} \right| = \frac{1}{6} |\cos \alpha (\sin \beta \sin \gamma) - \sin \alpha (\cos \beta \cos \gamma)|\]Let $\theta$ be the angle between $\mathbf{a}$ and $\mathbf{b},$ so $\alpha + \beta = \theta,$ and let $\phi$ be the angle between $\mathbf{b}$ and $\mathbf{c},$ so $\beta + \gamma = \phi.$  Then
\[\cos \alpha (\sin \beta \sin \gamma) - \sin \alpha (\cos \beta \cos \gamma) = \cos \alpha \cos \phi \sin \gamma - \sin \alpha \sin \phi \cos \gamma\]Expanding, we get
\[\cos \theta \cos \phi \sin \gamma - \sin \theta \sin \phi \cos \gamma = \cos (\theta + \phi - \gamma).\]Hence, the volume of the tetrahedron is
\[\frac{1}{6} \left| \cos \theta \cos \phi \sin \gamma - \sin \theta \sin \phi \cos \gamma \right| = \frac{1}{6} |\cos (\theta + \phi - \gamma)|.\]Thus,
\[3 \cos^2 \theta - 2 \cos^3 \theta = 3 \cos \theta - 2 \cos \theta = \cos \theta.\]Therefore, our final answer is $\boxed{\cos \theta}.$
